title: Darts news: Gerwyn Price calls for PDC to step in over crowd abuse
text:
Gerwyn Price wants the booing to stop (Picture: Getty Images)

Gerwyn Price thinks enough is enough with the abuse from the crowd he has to deal with and wants the PDC to deal with it in the same way UEFA has dealt with racism in football.

The world number five has become the pantomime villain of the oche over the last year, receiving relentless stick from the crowd at almost every venue he visits.

The tetchy relationship with the crowd stems from his controversial win in the Grand Slam of Darts final last year, when he was fined for gamesmanship in his win over Gary Anderson. However, he has also had high profile spats with the likes of James Wade and Daryl Gurney since, adding to the narrative of the ‘bad boy; role.

The Iceman fell early at the World Grand Prix earlier this month as the Dublin crowd really got on his back and he now says it has gone too far and the governing body needs to step in.

‘I’ve had a great year, but it has been difficult on the stage because of what goes on in the crowd, which is not on,’ Price told Metro.co.uk.

Price is hoping the fans will come round to his cause (Picture: Getty Images)

‘Sometimes I can deal with it but sometimes it really does put me off. There’s nothing I can do about it really, it’s something for the PDC to look at.

‘Like you saw in the football earlier this week with the racism in Bulgaria, they had two strikes and then the match would have been off. The PDC could look into something like that, the referee could give the fans warnings about it. In Dublin at the Grand Prix it was too much.’

Price is known for his vociferous celebrations to winning legs, or even hitting impressive scores mid-leg, which has known to rile opponents and fans in the past.

However, the Welshman says that this is all natural and part of his game, so is adamant that he won’t be changing, in fear of it impacting his game.

‘I don’t want to have to think about toning down my celebrations because they just come naturally, it’s not like I go up there thinking I’m going to do this and do that and give it the big one when I hit a certain thing.

‘So if I’m thinking about not doing them then I’m not playing my natural game, I’m over-thinking things and that will affect how I play.

‘I know a very popular number one in the world who does it more than me and never hears anything about it.’

The 34-year-old has tried to take measures to keep his concentration on stage, but none have helped and he admits that the crowd is a problem that could bother him again this weekend at the Champions League of Darts.

‘I’ve tried earplugs but I can still hear my own heart beating and other stuff, I’ve asked if I can have earphones in so I can listen to music up there but I’m not allowed to.

‘I might struggle a bit this weekend because I’ve not been playing much on stage but hopefully it will get better over the next few weeks as I get used to it again.

‘It would be nice if I could hit a nine-darter and get the crowd on my side, but then again I might just miss double 12 on purpose.’

Price will take on Peter Wright in Group B of the Champions League this weekend, and Snakebite believes the Iceman just needs to let his darts do the talking to keep the crowd quiet.

‘I don’t think you can do anything about that,’ Wright told Metro.co.uk. ‘Everyone’s got their own opinions of who they want to support.

I’ve had crowds booing me while I’m throwing, it’s just one of them things. He’s playing some good darts, so he’s not getting it as much as he used to, because he’s playing well and people respect the darts he’s throwing.

‘They’ll boo you one second; hit a 180 and they’ll cheer, so you have to just get on with it.’
